review.title: Measuring Offensive Speech in Online Political Discourse
review.abstract: The Internet and online forums such as Reddit have become an increasingly popular medium for citizens to engage in political conversations. However, the online disinhibition effect resulting from the ability to use pseudonymous identities may manifest in the form of offensive speech, consequently making political discussions more aggressive and polarizing than they already are. Such environments may result in harassment and self-censorship from its targets. In this paper, we present preliminary results from a large-scale temporal measurement aimed at quantifying offensiveness in online political discussions.

metadata.title: Measuring Offensive Speech in Online Political Discourse

sections.text: To make our measurements possible, we develop and evaluate an insulting language classifier, and then use that classifier to quantify and compare insult in a political and general context. We conduct our study using a database of over 168 million Reddit comments made by over 7 million pseudonyms between January 2015 and January 2017 - a period that includes several polarizing political events, including the 2016 US presidential election.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The apparent rise in policies has caught the attention of academics in recent years, who have increasingly focused on the extent to which politicians and elected officials use rhetoric that violates the norms of civility (such as Muslims, Mexicans, and African-Americans), and the consequences of such policies are indeed seen as critical to the functioning of democracy.

sections.heading: 2 Datasets
sections.text: Our study uses several non-political datasets to identify and characterize trends in offensive speech. CrowdFlower's hate speech dataset [1] contains 14.5K tweets, each labeled by at least three contributors. Contributors were allowed to classify each tweet into one of three classes: non-offensive (NO), offensive but not hateful (O), and offensive and hateful (OH). Of the 14.5K tweets, only 37.6% had a critical class - i.e., the same class was assigned by all contributors. In undecided cases, the majority class was selected and a class trust (fraction of posts that selected the majority class) was provided. Using this approach, 50.4%, 33.1%, and 16.5% of tweets were rated as NO, O, and OH.

sections.heading: 3 Offensive Speech Classification
sections.text: In order to identify offensive remarks, we propose a fully automatic technique that divides comments into two classes: offensive and emergency offensive.

sections.heading: 3.1 Classification approach
sections.text: In fact, we embed a list of offensive and hateful words identified by external data in a single vector, and then turn it into a single vector. In fact, it is as if it were a single vector in which a word can be embedded. Indeed, it is as if a word is embedded in a high-dimensional language. Indeed, it is as if it is a scalar that classifies its distance from the constructed hate-filled words as input to a random forest. Indeed, it is as if a word is embedded in a high-dimensional vector. In the way that semantic similarities between words are cultivated, it is classified as input to a random forest. This mapping is achieved by exploiting the distributed properties of words.

sections.heading: 3.2 Classifier evaluation
sections.text: We present the results to (1) validate our choice of classifier and (2) illustrate the impact of our training / validation sample count on our performance.Classifier selection methodology. To identify the most appropriate classifier for classifying the scalars associated with each text, we perform evaluations using the stochastic gradient Descent, naive Bayes, decision tree and random forest classifiers. For each classifier, we divide the CrowdFlower hate speech dataset into a training / validation set (25%).We perform 10-fold cross-validation on the training / validation set to identify the best classification model and parameters (using a grid search).Based on the results of this evaluation, we select a 100-estimator-based entropy-based forest model as our classifier F1 and show more accuracy for each one of the classifiers.

sections.heading: 4 Measurements
sections.text: In this section, we quantify and characterize openness in the political and general contexts in which we present our views.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: We note that political discussion on Reddit - measured by the frequency of offensive comments - became increasingly less civilized during the 2016 election campaign, even though more than three-quarters of the authors of such comments appear to have come from disposable accounts. While offensive posts in political subreddits, such as the one the campaign carried, have become increasingly common, there has been no such increase in apolitical forums. This contrast provides additional evidence that the increased use of offensive comments is directly related to the increase in the general election campaign for the president. Our findings provide a unique and important illustration of the increasing incidence of political discourse during the campaign.
